message.content: {"steps":[{"output":"Step 1 [Understanding the limit from the right]:","explanation":"The notation \\( \\lim\\limits_{x \\to -1^+} f(x) \\) indicates the limit of \\( f(x) \\) as \\( x \\) approaches \\( -1 \\) from the right. We need to examine the graph of \\( f(x) \\) to determine this value."},{"output":"Step 2 [Evaluating \\( \\lim\\limits_{x \\to -1^+} f(x) \\)]:","explanation":"From the graph, as \\( x \\) approaches \\( -1 \\) from the right, the value of \\( f(x) \\) approaches 2. Therefore, \\( \\lim\\limits_{x \\to -1^+} f(x) = 2 \\)."},{"output":"Step 3 [Understanding the limit from the right]:","explanation":"The notation \\( \\lim\\limits_{x \\to 0^+} f(x) \\) indicates the limit of \\( f(x) \\) as \\( x \\) approaches \\( 0 \\) from the right. We need to examine the graph of \\( f(x) \\) to determine this value."},{"output":"Step 4 [Evaluating \\( \\lim\\limits_{x \\to 0^+} f(x) \\)]:","explanation":"From the graph, as \\( x \\) approaches \\( 0 \\) from the right, the value of \\( f(x) \\) approaches 1. Therefore, \\( \\lim\\limits_{x \\to 0^+} f(x) = 1 \\)."},{"output":"Step 5 [Summation of limits]:","explanation":"Now, we sum the two limits: \\( \\lim\\limits_{x \\to -1^+} f(x) + \\lim\\limits_{x \\to 0^+} f(x) = 2 + 1 = 3 \\)."}],"final_answer":"\\MC: boxed{3}"}
